questions.text: Which reaction in the diagram below would be inhibited in the presence of large amounts of avidin, an egg white protein that binds and sequesters biotin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Avidin inhibits biotin absorption, and biotin is essential for the carboxylation reaction that converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate in gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: Vitamin B1 is a cofactor in RBC for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Transketolase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In RBCs, Vitamin B1 serves as a cofactor for the transketolase enzyme, which functions in the HMP shunt and does not involve energy production.

questions.text: Vitamin B1 is a cofactor for energy production for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B1 is a cofactor for energy production specifically in the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate, which produces ATP.

questions.text: Inulin-like fructans are used as prebiotics as they are non-digestible. Resistance to digestion in the upper GI tract results from:

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of digestive enzymes in the upper GI tract

questions.correct_answer: B. Beta configuration of anomeric C2
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Beta configuration of anomeric C2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inulin’s resistance to digestion in the upper GI tract is primarily due to the beta configuration at the anomeric carbon C2 of fructose.

questions.text: In preparation for a trip to an area of India where chloroquine-resistant malaria is endemic, a young man is given primaquine prophylactically. Soon thereafter, he develops a hemolytic condition due to a deficiency in glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase. A less-than-normal level of which of the following is a consequence of the enzyme deficiency and the underlying cause of the hemolysis?

options.label: B
options.text: Oxidized form of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reduced form of glutathione

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In G6PD deficiency, the inability to produce NADPH leads to a reduced level of glutathione, causing increased susceptibility to hemolysis under oxidative stress.

questions.text: A fifty-year-old man with type 1 diabetes is referred to an ophthalmologist for evaluation of developing cataract. Which of the following enzymes is most strongly associated with cataract formation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aldose reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aldose reductase is the enzyme responsible for converting excess glucose to sorbitol, which accumulates in the lens and leads to cataract formation in diabetic patients.

questions.text: A young man finds that every time he eats dairy products, he feels very uncomfortable. His stomach becomes distended. He develops gas and diarrhea frequently. These symptoms do not appear when he eats food other than dairy products. Which of the following is most likely enzyme in which this young man is deficient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Beta galactosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lactose intolerance is caused by a deficiency of lactase, also known as beta galactosidase , which leads to the inability to digest lactose in dairy products.
  • ➤ beta galactosidase

questions.text: Which complex of the ETC does not pump protons?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Complex II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complex II of the electron transport chain does not pump protons, in contrast to Complexes I, III, and IV, which contribute to the proton gradient necessary for ATP synthesis.
  • ➤ Complex II

questions.text: ADP to ATP conversion in mitochondria is affected by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oligomycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oligomycin directly inhibits ATP synthase, affecting the conversion of ADP to ATP in mitochondria.

questions.text: In glycolysis, inorganic phosphate is used in reactions catalysed by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase is the enzyme in glycolysis where inorganic phosphate is used, forming 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate.

questions.text: True statement about glucokinase are all except:

options.label: D
options.text: Glucose enter into cells through GLUT-2

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) G-6 P Inhibit it

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucokinase is found in the liver and pancreas, has a high Km value, is not inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate, and allows glucose entry through the GLUT-2 transporter.

questions.text: Insulin promotes lipogenesis by all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inhibiting pyruvate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Insulin promotes lipogenesis by activating pyruvate dehydrogenase, decreasing cAMP, and increasing glucose uptake, but does not inhibit pyruvate dehydrogenase .
  • ➤ does not inhibit pyruvate dehydrogenase

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy of middle-eastern ancestry is known to have inherited favism, a sensitivity to fava beans due to glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (MIM305900). Which of the following indicates the primary pathway affected by this deficiency and the pathway secondarily affected because one of its energy substrates will be deficient?

options.label: A
options.text: Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid synthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid oxidation

options.label: C
options.text: Citric acid cycle, pentose phosphate pathway

questions.correct_answer: A. Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid synthesis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pentose phosphate pathway, fatty acid synthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency primarily affects the pentose phosphate pathway, leading to a secondary impact on fatty acid synthesis due to the lack of NADPH.

questions.text: Enzyme common between glycogenesis and glycogenolysis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phosphoglucomutase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phosphoglucomutase is the enzyme common to both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis, enabling the interconversion of glucose-1-phosphate and glucose-6-phosphate.

questions.text: After overnight fasting, levels of glucose transporters reduced in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adipocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During fasting, insulin levels drop, leading to a decrease in glucose transporter levels in adipocytes, but not in brain cells, RBCs, or hepatocytes.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to his physician because of vomiting, night sweats, and tremors. History revealed that these symptoms began after fruit juices were introduced to his diet as he was being weaned off breast milk. The physical examination was remarkable for hepatomegaly. Tests on the baby’s urine were positive for reducing sugar but negative for glucose. The infant most likely suffers from a deficiency of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aldolase B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A deficiency in Aldolase B causes hereditary fructose intolerance, which can lead to hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly when fructose is ingested.
  • ➤ Aldolase B

questions.text: An enzyme involved in the catabolism of fructose to pyruvate in the liver is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate Dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase plays a crucial role in the conversion of fructose to pyruvate in the liver.

questions.text: Glucaric acid is formed from glucose by:

options.label: D
options.text: Oxidation of both aldehyde carbon and primary alcoholic group

questions.correct_answer: D. Oxidation of both aldehyde carbon and primary alcoholic group
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Oxidation of both aldehyde carbon and primary alcoholic group

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucaric acid is formed by the oxidation of both the aldehyde carbon (C1) and the primary alcohol group (C6) of glucose.

questions.text: The conversion of pyruvate to acetyl coenzyme A and carbon dioxide:

options.label: A
options.text: Involves the participation of lipoic acid.

options.label: B
options.text: Is activated when pyruvate decarboxylase of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDHC) is phosphorylated by PDH kinase in the presence of ATP.

questions.correct_answer: A. Involves the participation of lipoic acid.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Involves the participation of lipoic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA is an irreversible mitochondrial reaction that involves lipoic acid as a cofactor and is inhibited, not activated, by phosphorylation.

questions.text: Which one of the following reactions is unique to gluconeogenesis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Oxaloacetate → phosphoenolpyruvate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The conversion of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate is a reaction unique to gluconeogenesis and does not occur in glycolysis.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements concerning gluconeogenesis is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: It is important in maintaining blood glucose during a 2-day fast.

options.label: C
options.text: It is inhibited by a fall in the insulin/glucagon ratio.

options.label: D
options.text: It occurs in the cytosol of muscle cells.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is important in maintaining blood glucose during a 2-day fast.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is important in maintaining blood glucose during a 2-day fast

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gluconeogenesis is crucial for maintaining blood glucose levels during prolonged fasting, especially beyond 16-18 hours when liver glycogen stores are depleted.

questions.text: A 1-month-old male shows neurologic problems and lactic acidosis. Enzyme assay for pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDHC) activity on extracts of cultured skin fibroblasts showed 5% of normal activity with a low concentration of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) but 80% of normal activity when the assay contained a thousand-fold higher concentration of TPP. Which one of the following statements concerning this patient is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Administration of thiamine is expected to reduce his serum lactate level and improve his clinical symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: A high-carbohydrate diet would be expected to be beneficial for this patient.

options.label: C
options.text: Citrate production from aerobic glycolysis is expected to be increased.

options.label: D
options.text: PDH kinase, a regulatory enzyme of the PDHC, is expected to be active.

questions.correct_answer: A. Administration of thiamine is expected to reduce his serum lactate level and improve his clinical symptoms.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Administration of thiamine is expected to reduce his serum lactate level and improve his clinical symptoms.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiamine supplementation is beneficial for patients with pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency, as it increases enzyme activity and helps reduce lactic acidosis.

questions.text: ADP and ATP transfer in mitochondria is affected by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atractyloside

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atractyloside specifically inhibits the ADP/ATP translocase, blocking ADP and ATP exchange in the mitochondria.

questions.text: True about liver enzyme dephosphorylation to phosphorylation is:

options.label: C
options.text: More commonly seen in fed state than in fasting state

options.label: D
options.text: Always activated by cAMP dependent tyrosine kinase

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Catecholamines stimulate it

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Catecholamines stimulate the phosphorylation of liver enzymes by activating protein kinase A (PKA) via increased cyclic AMP levels.
  • ➤ protein kinase A (PKA)
  • ➤ cyclic AMP

questions.text: 2,4-Dinitrophenol (DNP), an uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation, was used as a weight-loss agent in the 1930s. Reports of fatal overdoses led to its discontinuation in 1939. Which of the following would most likely be true concerning individuals taking 2,4-DNP?

options.label: A
options.text: ATP levels in the mitochondria are greater than normal.

options.label: B
options.text: Body temperature is elevated as a result of hypermetabolism.

options.label: C
options.text: The proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane is greater than normal.

options.label: D
options.text: The rate of electron transport is abnormally low.

questions.correct_answer: B. Body temperature is elevated as a result of hypermetabolism.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Body temperature is elevated as a result of hypermetabolism.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 2,4-DNP disrupts oxidative phosphorylation by causing protons to leak across the inner mitochondrial membrane, resulting in decreased ATP production and increased body temperature due to hypermetabolism .
  • ➤ decreased ATP production
  • ➤ increased body temperature
  • ➤ hypermetabolism

questions.text: Identify the anaplerotic reaction among the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA

options.label: D
options.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid

questions.correct_answer: B. Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate is an anaplerotic reaction that replenishes TCA cycle intermediates , particularly oxaloacetate.
  • ➤ pyruvate to oxaloacetate
  • ➤ TCA cycle intermediates

questions.text: Glucosamines are used in which of the following conditions:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucosamine is commonly used in the treatment of arthritis , particularly to support joint health and alleviate symptoms of osteoarthritis .
  • ➤ arthritis
  • ➤ osteoarthritis

questions.text: Under anaerobic metabolism, which of the following substrates yields 3 molecules of ATP?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glycogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When glycogen is used as the substrate in anaerobic glycolysis, it yields 3 ATP due to the ATP savings in the initial conversion steps.
  • ➤ glycogen
  • ➤ 3 ATP

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was evaluated for burning sensations in his feet and clusters of small, red-purple spots on his skin. Laboratory studies revealed protein in his urine. Enzymatic analysis revealed a deficiency of α-galactosidase, and enzyme replacement therapy was recommended. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fabry disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fabry disease is characterized by a deficiency in α-galactosidase , leading to burning sensations, angiokeratomas, and kidney involvement.
  • ➤ Fabry disease
  • ➤ α-galactosidase

questions.text: Examples of monounsaturated fatty acids is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oleic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oleic acid is a primary example of a monounsaturated fatty acid (MUFA) found in olive oil.
  • ➤ Oleic acid
  • ➤ monounsaturated fatty acid (MUFA)

questions.text: Fatty acid which is omega 7 is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Palmitoleic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Palmitoleic acid is an example of an omega-7 fatty acid .
  • ➤ Palmitoleic acid
  • ➤ omega-7 fatty acid

questions.text: In which type of hypertriglyceridemia are chylomicrons and VLDL remnants increased?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Type III hyperlipoproteinemia , both chylomicrons and VLDL remnants are elevated due to a defect in ApoE .
  • ➤ Type III hyperlipoproteinemia
  • ➤ chylomicrons and VLDL remnants
  • ➤ ApoE

questions.text: A low-level carbon dioxide labeled with C14 is accidentally released into the atmosphere surrounding industrial workers as they resume work following the lunch hour. Unknowingly, they breathe the contaminated air for 1 hour. Which of the following compounds will be radioactively labeled?

options.label: A
options.text: All of the carbon atoms of newly synthesized fatty acids

options.label: B
options.text: About one half of the carbon atoms of newly synthesized fatty acids

options.label: C
options.text: About one third of the carbons of newly synthesized malonyl CoA

options.label: D
options.text: One half of the carbon atoms of newly synthesized acetyl CoA

questions.correct_answer: C. About one third of the carbons of newly synthesized malonyl CoA
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) About one third of the carbons of newly synthesized malonyl CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhalation of C14-labeled CO2 leads to about one-third of the carbons in malonyl-CoA being radioactively labeled, but this carbon is released during the condensation step of fatty acid synthesis , and fatty acids will not contain radioactive carbon.
  • ➤ C14-labeled CO2
  • ➤ one-third of the carbons in malonyl-CoA
  • ➤ fatty acid synthesis

questions.text: In the well-fed state, the Carnitine Acyl Transferase on the outer mitochondrial membrane is inhibited by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Malonyl CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the well-fed state, Malonyl CoA inhibits Carnitine Acyl Transferase I , preventing fatty acid transport into the mitochondria and favoring fat storage over fat breakdown .
  • ➤ Malonyl CoA
  • ➤ Carnitine Acyl Transferase I
  • ➤ fat storage
  • ➤ fat breakdown

questions.text: Beta oxidation of fatty acids in peroxisomes ends with formation of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Octanoyl CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peroxisomal beta oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids ends with the formation of octanoyl CoA , which is then transferred to mitochondria for further breakdown.
  • ➤ Peroxisomal beta oxidation
  • ➤ octanoyl CoA

questions.text: Accumulation of increased amount of sphingomyelin in liver and spleen is found in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Niemann-Pick disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Niemann-Pick disease , a deficiency of sphingomyelinase leads to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the liver and spleen.
  • ➤ Niemann-Pick disease
  • ➤ sphingomyelinase
  • ➤ sphingomyelin

questions.text: A young girl with a history of severe abdominal pain was taken to her local hospital at 5 a.m. in severe distress. Blood was drawn, and the plasma appeared milky, with the triacylglycerol level >2,000 mg/dl (normal = 4–150 mg/dl). Which of the following lipoprotein particles are most likely responsible for the appearance of the patient’s plasma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chylomicrons

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A milky plasma appearance due to high triacylglycerol levels is caused by elevated levels of chylomicrons , which are responsible for transporting dietary lipids.
  • ➤ milky plasma appearance
  • ➤ chylomicrons

questions.text: The enzymes responsible for sequential oxidation of fatty acids include which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dehydrogenase, hydratase, dehydrogenase, thiolase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The enzymes responsible for the sequential oxidation of fatty acids are dehydrogenase, hydratase, dehydrogenase, and thiolase .
  • ➤ dehydrogenase, hydratase, dehydrogenase, and thiolase

questions.text: In a pediatric patient diagnosed with Medium Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency, what metabolic complication is most likely to manifest during periods of fasting?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dicarboxylic acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MCAD deficiency impairs the body's ability to break down fats during fasting, leading to dicarboxylic acidosis rather than ketoacidosis. Recognizing and managing this disorder involves monitoring for and addressing metabolic complications associated with fasting

questions.text: The enzyme for cholesterol synthesis and ketone body synthesis and beta oxidation of fatty acid is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thiolase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiolase is a key enzyme common to cholesterol synthesis , ketone body formation , and beta-oxidation of fatty acids .
  • ➤ Thiolase
  • ➤ cholesterol synthesis
  • ➤ ketone body formation
  • ➤ beta-oxidation of fatty acids

questions.text: Which of the following is true about ketone bodies?

options.label: A
options.text: Acetoacetate is most common ketone body present in blood

options.label: B
options.text: Beta hydroxybutyrate is the first ketone body to be synthesized

questions.correct_answer: C. Thiophorase is absent in liver
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thiophorase is absent in liver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies due to the absence of thiophorase , despite being the site of ketone body synthesis.
  • ➤ absence of thiophorase

questions.text: The immediate precursor in the formation of acetoacetates from acetyl CoA in the liver is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HMG CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The immediate precursor for the formation of acetoacetate from acetyl CoA is HMG CoA .
  • ➤ acetoacetate
  • ➤ HMG CoA

questions.text: In beta oxidation of palmitic acid if the final product is acetoacetate, then the net gain of ATP is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 26

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When palmitic acid undergoes beta oxidation, and the final product is acetoacetate , the net ATP yield is 26 ATP.
  • ➤ palmitic acid
  • ➤ acetoacetate
  • ➤ 26

questions.text: In beta oxidation of palmitic acid, the net gain of ATP is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 106

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The net ATP gain from the complete beta oxidation of palmitic acid is 106 ATP .
  • ➤ net ATP gain
  • ➤ complete beta oxidation
  • ➤ palmitic acid
  • ➤ 106 ATP

questions.text: Acetyl CoA can be directly converted to all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetyl CoA cannot be converted directly into glucose due to the irreversible nature of the conversion from pyruvate to acetyl CoA.
  • ➤ glucose
  • ➤ irreversible

questions.text: A person on a fat-free carbohydrate-rich diet continues to grow obese. Which of the following lipoproteins is likely to be elevated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) VLDL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a fat-free, carbohydrate-rich diet, excess carbohydrates are converted to fat and transported by VLDL , leading to its elevation.
  • ➤ VLDL

questions.text: Which of the following is a powerful qualitative and quantitative technique to assess molecular mass and primary amino acid sequence of peptides and proteins?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mass spectrometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mass spectrometry is a powerful tool for determining both the molecular mass and primary sequence of peptides and proteins, making it invaluable for protein characterization.
  • ➤ Mass spectrometry
  • ➤ molecular mass
  • ➤ primary sequence

questions.text: Histamine is produced from histidine by decarboxylation. The cofactor is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin B6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate) is the required cofactor for the decarboxylation of histidine to produce histamine .
  • ➤ Vitamin B6
  • ➤ decarboxylation
  • ➤ histidine
  • ➤ histamine

questions.text: Structure of proteins can be determined by all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) SDS PAGE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SDS PAGE is used for the separation of proteins by molecular weight, but it does not provide any information about the structure of the protein.
  • ➤ SDS PAGE

questions.text: A child with a large head, multiple fractures, and blue scleras (whites of the eyes) is evaluated for osteogenesis imperfecta. One study involves labeling of collagen chains in tissue culture to assess their mobility by gel electrophoresis. Amino acids labeled with radioactive carbon 14 are added to the culture dishes in order to label the collagen. Which of the following amino acids would not result in labeled collagen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hydroxyproline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydroxyproline is a post-translationally modified amino acid and is not directly incorporated into collagen during synthesis, so it does not result in labeled collagen.
  • ➤ Hydroxyproline

questions.text: In this transamination reaction, which of the following are the products X and Y?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspartate, α-ketoglutarate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oxaloacetate is converted to aspartate in a transamination reaction, with glutamate being converted into α-ketoglutarate.

questions.text: Ingestion of benzoic acid in man results in an increase in urinary?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hippuric acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ingestion of benzoic acid results in the excretion of hippuric acid in the urine as part of the body's detoxification process.
  • ➤ benzoic acid
  • ➤ hippuric acid

questions.text: Indole ring is present in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tryptophan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The indole ring is specifically present in tryptophan , and it is a defining feature of this amino acid.
  • ➤ indole ring
  • ➤ tryptophan

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid will migrate slowest to the anode end at Physiological pH?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lysine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lysine migrates the slowest to the anode due to its positive charge at physiological pH.
  • ➤ Lysine

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about protein structure is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Proteins consisting of one polypeptide can have quaternary structure.

options.label: B
options.text: The formation of a disulfide bond in a protein requires that the two participating cysteine residues be adjacent to each other in the primary sequence of the protein.

options.label: C
options.text: The stability of quaternary structure in proteins is mainly a result of covalent bonds among the subunits.

options.label: D
options.text: The information required for the correct folding of a protein is contained in the specific sequences of amino acids along the polypeptide chain.

questions.correct_answer: D. The information required for the correct folding of a protein is contained in the specific sequences of amino acids along the polypeptide chain.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The information required for the correct folding of a protein is contained in the specific sequences of amino acids along the polypeptide chain.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The specific sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide chain dictates how the protein will fold and function, and cysteine residues can form disulfide bonds even if they are not adjacent in the primary sequence.

questions.text: Carbamoyl phosphate is involved in the synthesis of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pyrimidine and urea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carbamoyl phosphate is crucial for both pyrimidine synthesis and the urea cycle , but not for purine or uric acid metabolism.
  • ➤ pyrimidine synthesis
  • ➤ urea cycle

questions.text: Sulfhydryl group containing amino acid(s)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sulfhydryl group (-SH) is specifically found in cysteine , which allows it to form disulfide bonds essential for protein structure.
  • ➤ sulfhydryl group
  • ➤ cysteine

questions.text: Tryptophan is?

options.label: A
options.text: Non polar, essential and pure glucogenic

options.label: B
options.text: Polar, essential and both glucogenic & ketogenic

options.label: D
options.text: Non polar, essential, both glucogenic & ketogenic

questions.correct_answer: D. Non polar, essential, both glucogenic & ketogenic
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Non polar, essential, both glucogenic & ketogenic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tryptophan is a non-polar, essential amino acid that is both glucogenic and ketogenic, making it metabolically important for both glucose and ketone body production.
  • ➤ Tryptophan

questions.text: PKU is a congenital amino acid metabolic disorder. In one of the following rare variants of PKU, the enzyme deficient is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dihydropterin Reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In rare variants of PKU, the enzyme deficiency lies in dihydropterin reductase , leading to impaired regeneration of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) , which is essential for phenylalanine hydroxylase activity.
  • ➤ dihydropterin reductase
  • ➤ tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)

questions.text: Which of the following reactions occur both in mitochondria and cytosol?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urea Cycle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The urea cycle is unique in that it involves reactions both in the mitochondria and the cytosol, making it distinct from other processes like glycolysis and the TCA cycle​
  • ➤ urea cycle

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid cannot participate in transamination:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lysine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lysine, along with proline and threonine, cannot participate in transamination due to its structural properties.

questions.text: A particular point mutation results in disruption of the α-helical structure in a segment of the mutant protein. The most likely change in the primary structure of the mutant protein is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Methionine to proline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proline is not found in α-helical structures because it disrupts the helical conformation due to its rigid structure.

questions.text: A female neonate appeared healthy until age ~24 hours, when she became lethargic. A sepsis workup proved negative. At 56 hours, she started showing focal seizure activity. The plasma ammonia level was found to be 887 µmol/l (normal 5–35 µmol/l). Quantitative plasma amino acid levels revealed a marked elevation of citrulline but not argininosuccinate. Which one of the following enzymic activities is most likely to be deficient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Argininosuccinate synthetase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A deficiency in argininosuccinate synthetase results in elevated citrulline with normal argininosuccinate levels, causing hyperammonemia.
  • ➤ argininosuccinate synthetase

questions.text: δ-Aminolevulinic acid synthase activity:

options.label: A
options.text: Catalyzes the committed step in porphyrin biosynthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: Is decreased in the liver in individuals treated with certain drugs such as the barbiturate phenobarbital.

questions.correct_answer: A. Catalyzes the committed step in porphyrin biosynthesis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Catalyzes the committed step in porphyrin biosynthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ δ-Aminolevulinic acid synthase catalyzes the first committed step in porphyrin biosynthesis and is the rate-limiting enzyme that requires vitamin B6 as a cofactor.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought to his pediatrician for evaluation of gastrointestinal problems. The parents report that the boy has been listless for the last few weeks. Lab tests reveal a microcytic, hypochromic anemia. Blood lead levels are elevated. Which of the enzymes listed below is most likely to have higher-than-normal activity in the liver of this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) δ-Aminolevulinic acid synthase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lead poisoning inhibits enzymes like ferrochelatase and porphobilinogen synthase, resulting in increased activity of δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase.

questions.text: A tRNA molecule that is supposed to carry cysteine (tRNAcys) is mischarged, so that it actually carries alanine (ala-tRNAcys). Assuming no correction occurs, what will be the fate of this alanine residue during protein synthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: It will be incorporated into a protein in response to an alanine codon.

options.label: B
options.text: It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon.

options.label: C
options.text: It will remain attached to the tRNA. as it cannot be used for protein synthesis.

options.label: D
options.text: It will be chemically convened to cysteine by cellular-enzymes.

questions.correct_answer: B. It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fate of a mischarged tRNA is determined by its anticodon, meaning alanine will be incorporated into the protein at a position where cysteine is normally found.

questions.text: Apo B48, B100 belongs to same RNA, difference between them is due to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Differential RNA processing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The difference between Apo B48 and B100 is due to differential RNA processing , specifically RNA editing.
  • ➤ differential RNA processing

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be the recognition sequence for restriction endonuclease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) AATT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Restriction endonucleases recognize palindromic sequences, and AATT is a common recognition sequence for these enzymes.
  • ➤ AATT

questions.text: Number of high energy bonds required for the synthesis of Aminoacyl tRNA?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The synthesis of aminoacyl-tRNA requires 2 high-energy bonds in the form of ATP molecules.

questions.text: Degeneracy of codons means?

options.label: A
options.text: More than one codon for a single amino

questions.correct_answer: A. More than one codon for a single amino
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) More than one codon for a single amino

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Degeneracy of codons allows more than one codon to specify the same amino acid, contributing to genetic flexibility and silent mutations.

questions.text: Met tRNA would recognize?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) AUG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Met-tRNA specifically recognizes the AUG codon, which is the start codon for protein synthesis, coding for methionine.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the Wobble hypothesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Each amino acid is represented by only one codon

options.label: B
options.text: Base in third position of codon has reduced specificity for the same amino acid

options.label: C
options.text: Actively transported sugars are usually hexoses

options.label: D
options.text: Surface tension lowering substances get concentrated at interface

questions.correct_answer: B. Base in third position of codon has reduced specificity for the same amino acid
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Base in third position of codon has reduced specificity for the same amino acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Wobble hypothesis refers to the reduced specificity of the third base of the codon, allowing flexibility in coding for the same amino acid.

questions.text: Methylation of cytosine in gene causes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gene silencing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methylation of cytosine at the promoter region results in gene silencing.

questions.text: The hydrolytic step leading to the release of a polypeptide chain from a ribosome is catalyzed by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Peptidyl transferase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peptidyl transferase catalyzes the final release of the polypeptide chain from the ribosome at the P site, activated by recognition of the stop codon.

questions.text: The ZYA region of the lac operon will be efficiently transcribed if:

options.label: C
options.text: The operator is mutated and can't be bound by the repressor.

options.label: D
options.text: The repressor is mutated and can't be bound by the inducer.

questions.correct_answer: C. The operator is mutated and can't be bound by the repressor.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The operator is mutated and can't be bound by the repressor.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Efficient transcription of the ZYA region occurs when the operator is mutated and unable to bind the repressor, allowing RNA polymerase to transcribe the genes necessary for lactose metabolism.

questions.text: How do Di-Deoxy nucleotides inhibit DNA replication?

options.label: A
options.text: The analog becomes covalently bound to the enzyme and inhibits it

options.label: B
options.text: There is no 3’ Hydroxyl group to form the next phosphodiester bond

options.label: C
options.text: The analog can't form hydrogen bond to DNA template

options.label: D
options.text: Incorporation of the analog initiates rapid degradation of newly synthesized strand

questions.correct_answer: B. There is no 3’ Hydroxyl group to form the next phosphodiester bond
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) There is no 3’ Hydroxyl group to form the next phosphodiester bond.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Di-Deoxy nucleotides inhibit DNA replication by preventing the formation of phosphodiester bonds due to the absence of a 3' OH group.

questions.text: Restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis can only be used to follow the inheritance of a genetic disease if:

options.label: A
options.text: mRNA probe is used in combination with antibodies

options.label: B
options.text: The mutation is at or closely linked to restriction site

options.label: C
options.text: Mutation are outside of restriction sites so that cleaving still occurs

options.label: D
options.text: Restriction fragment remain the same size but their charge changes

questions.correct_answer: B. The mutation is at or closely linked to restriction site
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The mutation is at or closely linked to restriction site

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RFLP can only detect genetic mutations if they occur at or closely linked to a restriction site, which alters the DNA fragment sizes after digestion.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought by her parents to the dermatologist. She has many freckles on her face, neck, arms, and hands, and the parents report that she is unusually sensitive to sunlight. Two basal cell carcinomas are identified on her face. Based on the clinical picture, which of the following processes is most likely to be defective in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Repair of double-strand breaks by error-prone homologous recombination

options.label: B
options.text: Removal of mismatched bases from the 3′-end of Okazaki fragments by a methyl-directed process

options.label: C
options.text: Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA by nucleotide excision repair

options.label: D
options.text: Removal of uracil from DNA by base excision repair

questions.correct_answer: C. Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA by nucleotide excision repair
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA by nucleotide excision repair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The defect in the nucleotide excision repair mechanism leads to the accumulation of UV-induced pyrimidine dimers, resulting in clinical features such as sunlight sensitivity and skin cancers.

questions.text: In SCID, what type of DNA repair is defective:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Non-homologous end joining repair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In SCID, the defective DNA repair mechanism is non-homologous end joining, which is essential for repairing double-strand breaks.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child who easily tires and has trouble walking is diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, an X-linked recessive disorder. Genetic analysis shows that the patient’s gene for the muscle protein dystrophin contains a mutation in its promoter region. Of the choices listed, which would be the most likely effect of this mutation?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective.

options.label: B
options.text: Capping of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective.

options.label: C
options.text: Splicing of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective.

options.label: D
options.text: Tailing of dystrophin messenger RNA will be defective.

questions.correct_answer: A. Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A mutation in the promoter region affects the initiation of transcription by preventing proper binding of RNA polymerase, leading to defective transcription initiation.

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5'→3' Exonuclease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Klenow fragment lacks 5'→3' exonuclease activity but retains its 5'→3' polymerase and 3'→5' exonuclease proofreading activities.

questions.text: Shine Dalgarno sequence in bacterial mRNA is near:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) AUG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Shine-Dalgarno sequence helps ribosomes locate the AUG start codon to initiate protein synthesis in bacterial mRNA.

questions.text: Fidelity of protein translation depends upon:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aminoacyl tRNA Synthetase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aminoacyl tRNA synthetase is responsible for ensuring the accuracy of amino acid incorporation during protein translation through its proofreading activity.

questions.text: Which proofreading activity is critical in determining the accuracy of nuclear DNA replication?

options.label: A
options.text: 3’ to 5’ polymerase activity of DNA pol δ

options.label: B
options.text: 3’ to 5’ exonuclease activity of DNA pol γ

options.label: C
options.text: 5’ to 3’ polymerase activity of DNA pol III

options.label: D
options.text: 3’ to 5’ exonuclease activity of DNA pol δ

questions.correct_answer: D. 3’ to 5’ exonuclease activity of DNA pol δ
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 3’ to 5’ exonuclease activity of DNA pol δ

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 3’ to 5’ exonuclease activity of DNA polymerase δ is essential for the proofreading and accuracy of nuclear DNA replication.

questions.text: Primers are removed by all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Beta polymerase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta polymerase does not participate in primer removal; it is involved in DNA repair, unlike delta polymerase, RNase H1, and FEN1, which are active in the primer removal process.

questions.text: Nitrogen atoms in purines are derived from all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glutamate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nitrogen atoms in purines come from aspartate, glutamine, and glycine, but not from glutamate.

questions.text: SYBR green dye is used in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Real-time PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SYBR green dye is specifically used in real-time PCR to bind to double-stranded DNA and allow for the quantification of DNA synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following codon does not show degeneracy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Methionine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methionine is unique in that it is encoded by a single codon, AUG, and does not display codon degeneracy.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a cofactor and not a coenzyme?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Copper

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Copper is a cofactor and not a coenzyme because it is a metal ion, while the other options are organic molecules acting as coenzymes.

questions.text: A buffer that is most effective at pH of about 6.1 is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bicarbonate Buffer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bicarbonate buffer is most effective at a pH of about 6.1 due to its pKa being closest to this value.

questions.text: Which among the following serves as a cofactor for Glycogen phosphorylase:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pyridoxal Phosphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyridoxal phosphate (Vitamin B6) is the essential cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase, which is involved in glycogen breakdown.

questions.text: Arsenic poisoning inhibits:

options.label: C
options.text: Branched chain alfa keto acid dehydrogenase

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arsenic inhibits multiple dehydrogenase enzymes by binding to lipoic acid, an essential cofactor for their activity.

questions.text: In Vitamin C deficiency, post-translational modification of which amino acid is defective?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lysine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin C is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline during collagen synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins can act without phosphorylation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lipoamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipoamide is a vitamin cofactor that does not require phosphorylation to function, unlike pyridoxine, niacin, and thiamine.

questions.text: A lethal mutation occurs in a bacterium, rendering it incapable of replicating its chromosome. Because of this mutation, DNA synthesis produces many short fragments of DNA that have RNA sequences at their 5’ ends. The mutation is most likely in a gene encoding which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) DNA polymerase I

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A mutation in the gene encoding DNA polymerase I results in defective primer removal, leading to the accumulation of short DNA fragments with RNA sequences at their 5' ends.

questions.text: Oligomer with a mutant base substitution is used in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Site-directed mutagenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Site-directed mutagenesis involves the use of oligonucleotides with mutant base substitutions to introduce specific mutations into DNA for research purposes.

questions.text: Cytosolic Cytochrome C mediates:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Apoptosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cytosolic cytochrome C mediates apoptosis, not electron transport or other cellular processes.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company is studying a new antibiotic that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. When this antibiotic is added to an in vitro protein synthesis system that is translating the messenger RNA sequence AUGUUUUUUUAG, the only product formed is the dipeptide fMet-Phe. What step in protein synthesis is most likely inhibited by the antibiotic?

options.label: B
options.text: Binding of a charged transfer RNA to the ribosomal A site

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ribosomal translocation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inhibition of ribosomal translocation prevents further elongation, leading to the accumulation of dipeptides.

questions.text: Digestive enzymes are:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hydrolases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Digestive enzymes function as hydrolases, catalyzing the breakdown of complex molecules during digestion.

questions.text: Tyrosinase is a:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oxidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tyrosinase is an oxidase enzyme that plays a key role in melanin biosynthesis.
